Turned out delicious (even the few that were a little overdone). They are so good, we've been eating them like potato chips...but next time, will be sure to keep some on hand for recipes, etc. So yummy...thank you!
Wonderful, thanks!
These are so dang good! Very addicting! Thanks for the great recipe, we needed a way to use up some of the tomatoes from the garden.
I have a large abundance of Roma tomatoes this year and this recipe helped us use them up. Very easy to do and my kitchen smelled wonderful. I love using fresh herbs and garlic on these. Thanks!

This is an outstanding recipe that is a great solution for using up tomatoes when you have far too many! Of course, you can just buy tomatoes specifically to have dried tomatoes on hand. The herbs, garlic and olive oil add good flavor. I'll be making this during the summer when my tomatoes are yielding their fruits (should be a lot!).
Used packaged itilian seasonings
Wow! These were awesome. I used grape tomatoes cut in half, baked it for 2 hours and broiled it for 30 mins, then served it in a chicken and garlic sauce over pasta. Everybody loved it!

The grocers won't like you... Imagine. Giving a simple, wonderful recipe that will be used over and over again and for just pennies on the dollar. I am so pleased that you posted this. It will get passed on to family and friends. Thank you so much.
In my opinion, these are better than chocolate and maybe better than sex. Wow! What a way to use up crop of tomatoes. Thanks.

These are fabulous. Forgot to buy sun dried tomatoes but had just bought fresh vine-ripened at Costco so I checked out this recipe and was not disappointed. Ate half of them as I removed them from the oven. Some got a little crunchy and were delicious. Now I will make my barley lentil soup with sun dried tomatoes. I will use this recipe again for sure. THANKS

This makes a great snack; sweet and intense, as another reviewer said. I made these in my dehydrator at 155 degrees for 5 hours. I used 8 small tomatoes, but would recommend using a lot more tomatoes to go with the 4 Tbsp of herbs. I found it a little difficult to measure the herbs but not the tomatoes, so I just used fresh garlic and dried basil and oregano to my tastes. I really enjoyed eating these, and will probably add some in stew or italian casseroles. Thanks for a different and delicious use for tomatoes!

I went to the Houston Farmer's Market and bought pounds and pounds of very ripe tomatoes for $.50 per pound. Spent a little time prepping them for this recipe with dried and fresh herbs mixed with lemon juice and lotsa garlic. My large Roma tomatoes took 5 hours in a dehydrating toaster oven and BOY did my house smell great the whole time! I put the tomatoes in olive oil with feta cheese chunks and peppercorns, and had a real feast with the tomato/feta mixture eaten with fresh french bread slices. Yummy!

It's great to have an alternative to canning for my abundant tomato harvest! These, with their intensely sweet tomato taste, are better than Craisins! I liked setting the prepared tomatoes cut-side up so that they functioned as miniature bowls. The "little bowls" then contained the olive oil and herbs (mostly dried basil with a light touch of course-ground garlic salt) which gradually infused into the tomatoes during dehydration. It took the smaller tomatoes ('Fox' large cherry-type and 'Principe Borghese' Italian drying tomatoes) 6 hours and the larger ('Viva Italia' paste-type) 8+ hours to complete the drying process. Thanks for providing great instructions for homemade "Sun Dried" Tomatoes!

Delicious, easy to make. I used several kinds of tomatoes, Roma's, large red, yellow and large cherry. The roma's & cherry tomatoes did the best for drying time, 6 hours. The larger tomatoes had a long way to go so we ate them with our dinner, YUMMY. I used extra virgin olive oil, fresh basil, doubled the amount of garlic and didn't use the oregano, personal preference.Then packed then into a small jar with extra virgin oil to preserve them & stored in refrigerator. I plan to make more as soon as I have more ripe roma's these would make a good snack. Thanks for posting this yummy recipe.

Not enough stars for this recipe. I used large meaty tomatoes, so total oven time was 12 hours. I ate a few when they were done and preserved the rest in olive oil in the fridge. I think next time I will use roma or large cherry tomatoes to cut down on drying time. These are so worth the wait...next batch will be a quadruple at least!!!

These are great. I baked them overnight for a total of 14-hours. My tomatoes were huge and very meaty, so I quartered them. I could not stop popping them in my mouth as I was taking them out of the oven.I am storing them in the fridge in a jar of olive oil and garlic. This will make a delicious tomato pesto. Thanks for such a nice recipe, Gerry.

These were fabulous!! I used 6 tomatoes and baked them for 5 hours. I needed them for a recipe, but I couldn't stop munching on them, they tasted so good!!! I'll never use the store bought again. Thanks for a keeper.

These were so easy to make. I also used grape tomatoes. Instead of using the oven, I used my food dehydrator and this worked great. I dehydrated some of them until they were crunchy. Great just to throw on salads or just eat as a snack. Thanks for posting.

This recipe is so easy and the tomatoes turned out great! I baked them for 6 hours and used fresh basil (from the garden) and 1 teaspoon dried oregano. I have two tomato plants that are loaded down with tomatoes and this was the perfect recipe to help use them up. I will definitely use this recipe again!

I don't know why I didn't review these before-I'm on my second batch! They are great, I use the grape tomatoes, cut them in half and don't worry about removing the seeds. They don't take as long to dry, and I store them in the refrigerator with a little olive oil. Thanks for a great way to keep tomatoes that might otherwise get old and have to be thrown out. Carole in Orlando
